Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I'd suggest doing a linear search before trying to do a binary search.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: As the pset says: "Before you implement search in O(log n) time, you might want to implement it temporarily in O(n) time, as with linear search, if only because it’s a bit easier to get right. That way, you can move on to sort, knowing that search already works. And once sort works, you can go back and re-implement search in O(log n) time, as with binary search. Just remember to!"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
so you have a counting array that holds the number of times each value in your original array appeared.  So let's say your counting array looks like this: ```{1,0,1,4,2}
 0,1,2,3,4   values``` which means you have 8 values in your original values array.  You now need to loop over the counting array and replace those 8 values in the original array with the values in sorted order.  So, value[0] would be 0, value[1] would be 2, value[2] would be 3, value[3] would be 3, value[4] would be 3, value[5] would be 3, value[6] would be 4, value[7] would be 4.  And the loop ends, since you replaced all 8 values in the array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ie, you have 1 zero, 1 two, 4 threes, and 2 fours.  ```{0,2,3,3,3,3,4,4}```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @JZ your screenshot was showing 27 and 29 and a mid of 28.   But when calculating the mid/max of the array, it is the index values that are important, not the actual numbers in the array.  (it's only once you find the right "mid" index value that you then compare the value at that point in the array to the value you are searching for.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you have an array {10, 20, 30, 40}, then min is 0 and max is 3 ...
